Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 2
Page 2
COMMENTS
Overall auction offerings declined further and totalled 5.2 M/Kgs of which approximately 0.6 M/Kgs comprised of re-prints. Good general demand perhaps triggered by the restricted availability.
Ex-Estate offerings comprised of 0.7 M/Kgs. Overall quality of teas on offer showed no significant change and an irregular trend in prices often following quality.
Better Western BOP's declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the corresponding BOPF's were firm and up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer. In the Below Best category, BOP's in the higher price bracket declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others were firm. Corresponding BOPF's in the higher price bracket were irregular following quality, whilst the others sold around last week's levels. At the lower end of the market, BOP's were firm and dearer, whilst the corresponding BOPF's were generally firm. Nuwara Eliyas' were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa BOP/BOPF's gained by up to Rs. 50 per kg and Rs. 20-40 per kg respectively, although still continued to sell at lower end of the market. Uvas' - Seasonal teas continued to sell well though at slightly lower levels to last with the BOP's ranging between Rs. 2,400-2,900 per kg and the corresponding BOPF's selling between Rs. 1,800-1,900 per kg. Other non-seasonal teas sold around last week's levels.
CTC teas were generally firm, whilst the corresponding Low Grown varieties witnessed a little more buyer activity this week.
A selection of liquoring Large Leaf teas attracted fairly useful support and sold well.
Selective interest from shippers to the UK. Fair activity from shipper to the continent, Japan and perhaps China. Less activity from shippers to South Africa, whilst shippers to the Middle East and the CIS continued to operate as usual.
Low Growns totalled approximately 2.3 M/Kgs, with the Leafy category witnessing less demand, whilst the Semi-Leafy, Tippy and Premium categories met with fair demand.
In the Leafy and Semi-Leafy catalogues, well-made BOP1's were firm, whilst the Below Best together with the bolder varieties were easier. Teas at the bottom maintained. Select Best and Best OP1's were easier, whilst the Below Best together with the bolder varieties appreciated. Teas at the bottom followed a similar trend.  Well-made OP's were firm, whilst balance appreciated. High-priced OPA's gained, whilst the balance were firm to dearer following quality. PEK/PEK1's, in general, appreciated., whilst the smaller PEK1 varieties sold around last levels.
In the Tippy catalogue, Select Best FBOP's were firm to easier. Best together with the Below Best varieties were firm on last, whilst the balance eased. However, a selection of bolder varieties appreciated, whilst the balance sold at last levels. Select Best FF1's were firm. Best together with the cleaner Below Best and cleaner teas at the bottom were firm, whilst the balance together with the teas at the bottom were easier.
In the Premium catalogue, Very Tippy Teas were firm to dearer, whilst the Best and Below Best were firm following quality. Balance together with the Leafier varieties were easier.
NOTE
Next week's Auction (Sale No. 34) is scheduled for Monday, 1 September and Tuesday, 2 September 2025
SRI LANKA TEA EXPORTS - JULY 2025
Key Highlights:
* Sri Lanka Tea Exports for the month was recorded at 24.04 M/Kgs - (Increase of 2.68 M/Kgs YoY)
* Exports during the cumulative period totalled 150.85 M/Kgs (Increase of 10.38 M/Kgs YoY) in comparison with January-July 2024 total of 140.47 M/Kgs
* Value Added tea exports during the cumulative period totalled 58% from a 52% during the corresponding period in 2024
* F.O.B value for the month was Rs. 1,766.51 (USD 5.87), recording a decline of Rs. 7.19 (Increase of USD 0.03) against the corresponding period of 2024. Cumulative FOB value declined by Rs. 22.94 in comparison with the corresponding period of 2024, whilst to-date USD earnings continued to show an overall improvement in all categories except for Packeted Tea
* Iraq continues to maintain the top position amongst leading importer countries of Ceylon Tea for the year, whilst Libya remains at 2
nd
place and Russia in third
JULY 2025/2024
* Tea Exports for the month of July 2025 totalled 24.04 M/Kgs, showing an increase of 2.68 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 21.36 M/Kgs of July 2024. All categories have recorded positive variances in comparison with the corresponding period of the previous year.
* FOB value in July 2025 was recorded at Rs. 1,766.51, a decrease of Rs. 7.19 YoY compared to R
s. 1,773.70 of July 2024. In USD terms, however, the month of July witnessed a marginal gain of USD 0.03 in comparison with the corresponding period in the year 2024 (Refer table below).
JANUARY-JULY 2025/2024
* January-July 2025 cumulative exports totalled 150.85 M/Kgs, recording a positive variance of 10.38 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 140.47 M/Kgs of January-July 2024. All segments, except for Bulk Tea, have recorded positive variances against the same period of the previous year.
* FOB value for the period stood at Rs. 1,748.51, a decrease of Rs. 22.94 (Increase of USD 0.08) vis-à-vis Rs. 1,771.45 of January-July 2024.
* In terms of category-wise exports, Tea in Bulk, Tea Packets and Green Tea segments recorded negative variances, whilst Tea Bags and Instant Tea segments recorded gains in LKR terms in FOB value. Gains were recorded in USD terms in all categories except for Tea Packets when compared to the corresponding period in 2024 (Refer table below).
Iraq ranks at No. 1 amongst major importers of Ceylon Tea with a total of 22.61 M/Kgs, an increase of 27% YoY in January-July 2025 against the previous year's 17.84 M/Kgs, with Libya coming in 2
nd
place with 13.02 M/Kgs, an improvement of 245% ahead of Russia at 3
rd
place who has witnessed a significant decline of 13% YoY with 13.00 M/Kgs vis-à-vis 15.02 M/Kgs recorded in 2024. The U.A.E ranks at 4
th
place with 10.63 M/Kgs (24% decrease YoY) followed by Türkiye who has recorded 10.39 M/Kgs (2% decrease YoY) surpassing Iran at 6
th
place with 7.07 M/Kgs. Chile has secured 7
th
place with 6.51 M/Kgs continuing to stay ahead of China's 6.06 M/Kgs, Saudi Arabia's 4.88M/Kgs and Azerbaijan's 4.80 M/Kgs for the year in progress.
(Refer statistical details on Pages Nos. 9 and 10)
FORBES & WALKER TEA BROKERS (PVT) LTD SALE OF - 26TH/ 27TH AUGUST 2025
Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 3
Page 3
MARKET
Good demand at irregular rates
HIGH GROWN TEAS
BOP
Best Western's were mostly easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg following quality. In the Below Best category, teas in the higher price bracket declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg, whilst the others were firm. Teas at the lower end of the market were firm and dearer by a similar margin. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's gained by Rs. 50 per kg and more. Uva's - Seasonal teas continued to sell well in keeping with quality and prices ranged between Rs. 2,400-2,900 per kg, whilst the non-seasonal types continued to sell around last week's levels.
BOPF
Best Western's - Select high-priced teas were firm and up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer, whilst the others too sold well although prices were irregular following quality. In the Below Best category, prices for teas in the higher price bracket were irregular following quality, whilst the others sold around last week's levels. Teas at the lower end of the market were generally firm. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's were Rs. 20-40 per kg dearer. Uva's - Seasonal teas sold well though lower to last with prices ranging between Rs. 1,800-1,900 per kg, whilst the non-seasonal types continued to sell around last week's levels.
OP/OPA
Well-made varieties were firm to dearer by Rs. 20 per kg, whilst the others and poorer sorts were firm on last levels.
PEKOE/PEKOE1
Flavoury PEK's were firm, whilst the Orthodox Leafy PEK's were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg and more at times. Best PEK1's were dearer by Rs. 30-50 per kg. Teas at the lower end were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg. Few Select Best Rotovane PEK's sold at last levels following special inquiry, whilst the balance declined by Rs. 50 per kg and more. Below Best varieties were irregular but mostly firm. Poorer sorts sold at last levels.
FBOP/FBOPF1
Flavoury FBOP/FBOPF1's were firm to selectively dearer, whilst the poorer sorts were firm to easier by Rs. 20-40 per kg. Better Orthodox FBOP/FBOPF1's appreciated by Rs. 40-60 per kg, whilst the others and teas at the lower end were firm to dearer by Rs. 20-40 per kg.

FGS1/FGS
A few invoices in the Best category appreciated, whilst the others declined by Rs. 40 per kg following quality. Improved Below Best sorts were firm to dearer, whilst the others maintained. Teas at the lower end of the market appreciated. Low Growns- Clean leaf varieties were firm on last, whilst the teas at the bottom end of the market gained. CTC - In general, were firm.
BROKENS
Reducer varieties in the Best category were firm to selectively dearer. Clean leaf varieties in the Best category were easier by Rs. 20 per kg, whilst the others maintained. Teas at the bottom end of the market appreciated by Rs. 20 per kg.
BOP1A
Main Grade reducer varieties in the Best category were substantially dearer following quality, whilst the balance maintained. Below Best together with the poorer sorts were firm, whilst select invoices were easier by Rs. 20 per kg.

CROP AND WEATHER
For the period 19 - 26 August 2025
Western/Nuwara Eliya Regions
The Western and Nuwara Eliya regions reported bright weather throughout the week. Intermittent showers are expected in both regions in the week ahead according to the Department of Meteorology.
Uva/Uda Pussellawa Regions
Sunny weather was reported in the Uva and Uda Pussellawa regions throughout the week. According to the Department of Meteorology, rain is expected in the Uda Pussellawa and Uva regions in the week ahead.
Low Growns
The Low Grown Region reported bright weather throughout the week. The Department of Meteorology expects rain in the Low Grown Region in the week ahead.
Crop Intake
The Western and Nuwara Eliya regions maintained the crop intake, whilst the Uva, Uda Pussellawa and Low Grown regions reported a decrease.

MOMBASA AUCTION
SALE OF - 25TH AND 26TH AUGUST 2025 (SALE NO.34)
There was good general demand for 153,360 packages (10,376,062.00 kilos) on offer with 37.19% unsold.
MARKETS
Pakistan Packers were active but at lower levels with more interest from Yemen and other Middle Eastern countries. There was maintained participation from Afghanistan and Egyptian Packers. Kazakhstan and other CIS states lent support with Bazaar maintaining enquiry although were quite selective. UK were more active with Russia showing less interest and were quite selective. Sudan and South Sudan remained absent. Local Packers operated selectively while Somalia continued active at the lower end of the market.
OFFERINGS
Leaf Grades                    -    80,800 packages (5,312,450.00 kilos) - 42.03% unsold.
Dust Grades                  -   57,480 packages (4,286,842.00 kilos) - 37.51% unsold.
Secondary Grades          -   15,080 packages (   776,770.00 kilos) - 10.08% unsold.
LEAF GRADES (M2 & M3)
BP1:
Best - Were irregularly absorbed with select lines gaining by up to USC39 while others were easier by up to USC41.
Brighter - Firm to easier with few invoices shedding up to USC48 while the remainder ranged between USC10 to USC45 dearer.
Mediums - KTDA mediums were dearer with select teas advancing by up to USC10 while a few lines eased by up to USC12; plantation mediums appreciated by up to USC18.
Lower Medium - Were firm to USC18 above previous rates.
Plainer - Steady and varied between USC8 to USC27 dearer to easier by up to USC12.
PF1:
Best - Met irregular interest and ranged between firm to USC24 above previous levels while some lines shed up to USC20.
Brighter - Were generally easier by up to USC20 with a few invoices gaining by USC6 to USC24.
Mediums - KTDA mediums were steady to dearer by up to USC19 while some teas shed by USC2 to USC12. Plantation mediums appreciated by up to USC10.
Lower Medium - Were firm to easier by up to USC17.
Plainer - Some irregular interest varying between steady to dearer by USC3 to USC11 while select lines lost up to USC8.

PDUST:
Best - Were irregular ranging between USC3 to USC11 dearer to easier by up to USC18.
Brighter - Firm to dearer by up to USC12 but a few invoices shed up to USC8.
Mediums - KTDA mediums were steady to USC8 dearer with a select few gaining up to USC16 to mostly easier by up to USC17 with plantation mediums appreciating by up to USC9.
Lower Medium - Dearer by up to USC15 but few selected teas were firm to USC6 easier.
Plainer - Met strong support ranging between USC14 above previous rates to easier by up to USC11.
DUST1:

Brighter - Were firm to easier by up to USC7 but a select few gained by up to USC32.
Mediums - KTDA mediums met more irregular enquiry ranging between USC9 to USC18 above previous rates to easier by USC14 with plantation mediums up to USC9 dearer.
Lower Medium - Up to USC8 dearer to easier by up to USC4.
Plainer - Some irregular interest varying between steady to USC11 dearer to USC3 below previous rates.

SECONDARY GRADES (S1)
In the Secondary Catalogues, best BPs were barely steady while others were discounted; PFs tended dearer. Clean well sorted coloury Fannings appreciated with similar DUSTs mostly selling above previous levels. Other Fannings held value while DUSTs gained. BMFs were well absorbed.

AFRICA TEA BROKERS LTD
BANGLADESH AUCTION
SALE OF - 25TH AUGUST 2025 (SALE NO.16)
CTC LEAF: 53,076 packages of tea on offer met with a fairly good demand.
BROKENS: Well made good liquoring BOPs were in good demand and were generally firm on last. Smaller varieties in this category were well sought after at generally firm rates. Medium and plain types met with a fair demand with more withdrawals. BLF teas met with fair demand but there were several withdrawals.
FANNINGS: All good liquoring Fannings met with a fairly good demand but eased a little whilst Medium types met with fair interest and held last levels. Plain types were in less demand and there were again fair withdrawals. BLF teas met with fair demand but there were several withdrawals.
DUST: 13,567 packages of tea on offer met with a fair demand. Good liquoring Dusts sold at around last levels. Mediums again were an easier market with Tk.3/- to Tk.5/- less than last. Plain/BLF Dusts were a fair market with some withdrawals. Blenders lent strong support with fair interest from the Loose tea buyers.
COMMENTS: Blenders were fairly active this week but there was less competition from Loose tea buyers. As a result the absorption was less and consequently there were more withdrawals.
Dusts were a fair market.
Our Catalogue: (Sale 16) Avg : Tk 246.66, Sold 70.73% , (Sale 15) Avg : Tk 245.58, Sold 75.55%

JAKARTA AUCTION
SALE OF - 23RD AUGUST 2025 (SALE NO.34)
The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was 79.62%(1211750.56kgs) of the total offering of 1521930.25Kgs
DEMAND: - Good demand.
MARKET: - Best category prices were erratic closely following quality. Good teas met with very selective demand
with prices irregular and easier and also few out lots due to want of bids. Better medium & medium sorts ruled a barely steady to easier prices. Select blacker fanning in this category sold dearer on competition. Plainer sorts sold barely steady prices.
BUYING PATTERN: - Regional & local buyers were fairly active on best categories but selective on good teas. Major blenders and up country were active on the remainders. Exporters to Russia, CIS and middle east were active on the medium and plainer sorts. Iraqi shippers were active on larger broken at the lower level. Major blenders picked up 42.57% of the CTC Leaf sold.
ORTHODOX LEAF
Demand:- Good Demand.
Market:- High grown:- Well made, clean whole leaf & broken sold dearer on competition but the lower end saw a slight decline. Fanning grade were easier by Rs 2 to 5. Others category all teas sold at barely steady prices.
Buying Pattern:- CIS buyers were active on cleaner blacker varieties along with Internal buyers. Shippers to middle east operated on select whole leaf grades and broken. Internal were very choosy.
CTC DUST
DEMAND: - Good demand.
MARKET: - CTC dust offer this week was at 363055.22Kgs of which 337933.01kgs were sold (93.08%). Best category dust sold barely steady. Good teas were irregular. Remainders sold fully firm to dearer especially the finer dust.
BUYING PATTERN: - Regional and local packers were selective on the best & good teas. Exporters to Russia, Middle east continued to be active on blacker sorts. Other up country buyers were rather choosy.
ORTHODOX DUST
DEMAND: - Selective demand.
MARKET: - High grown primary dust fetched barely steady prices. Clean, medium grown teas sold firm dearer whilst others were discounted. Secondaries were barely steady to easier.
BUYING PATTERN: -Regional & local packers were selective on primary dusts. Exporters were very choosy at steady to easier prices on the secondary dusts.
Courtesy - J Thomas & Company Private Limited
